facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1011 and 1012 of 1966 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1011 and 1012 of 1966. Appeals by special leave from the judgments and decrees dated February 12, 1965 and November 10, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos. 298 of 1960 and 483 of 1962 respectively.

facts.text: Appeals from Allahabad High Court judgments dated February 12, 1965 in Special Appeal No. 298 of 1960 and November 10, 1964 in Special Appeal No. 483 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgments and decrees dated February 12, 1965 and November 10, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos. 298 of 1960 and 483 of 1962 respectively. N. Dixit and 0. P. Rana, for the appellants  in both the appeals . S. Barlingay, M. K. Pandey, S. K. Sabharwal and Ganpat Rai, for the respondents  in both the appeals .

facts.text: Jugal Kishore Bhatt appointed as Sales-tax Officer on June 29, 1948 by Governor of U.P.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in Civil Appeal No. 1012 of 1966, Jugal Kishore Bhatt was appointed as the Sales-tax Officer on June 29, 1948 by the Governor of U.P. At the time of his appointment the posts of Sales-tax Officers were temporary posts.

facts.text: Jugal Kishore Bhatt joined service in Sales-tax department at Bareilly on July 15, 1948 on temporary basis.

anchor.surface_text: He joined the service in the Sales-tax department at Bareilly on July 15, 1948. His appointment was on temporary basis. He companysidered to serve in that department as Sales- tax Officer until the year 1951 on temporary basis.

facts.text: Jugal Kishore Bhatt continued as Sales-tax Officer until 1951 on temporary basis.

anchor.surface_text: He companysidered to serve in that department as Sales- tax Officer until the year 1951 on temporary basis. In that year the Government issued G.O. No. ST 419/X-941.

facts.text: Government issued G.O. No. ST 419/X-941 in 1951 declaring appointments to certain posts substantive capacity with retrospective effect from first appointments.

anchor.surface_text: In that year the Government issued G.O. No. ST 419/X-941. Paragraph 4 of that order provided that as the posts detailed in the list annexed to the G.O. are likely to last for more than three years, the Governor is pleased to declare that the appointments made to those posts will be deemed to have been made in a substantive capacity and the incumbents thereof  shown in the list  other than those who are appointed to officiate in leave vacancies shall be treated as holders of those posts in a substantive capacity within the meaning of the order of the Governor regarding Fundamental Rule 26 d  of the Financial Handbook, Volume II, Part II with retrospective effect from the date of their first appoint- ments to those posts.

facts.text: Governor of U.P. made rule under Art. 309 in 1953 for termination of temporary service by one month notice.

anchor.surface_text: In that year the Governor of U.P. in exercise of the powers conferred upon him by the provisions of Art. 309 of the Constitution made the following rule Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any existing rules and orders on the subject, the services of a Government servant in temporary service shall be liable to termination at any time by notice in writing given either by the Government servant to the appointing authority or by the appointing authority to the government servant.

facts.text: In February 1953, Jugal Kishore Bhatt informed his appointment would terminate on March 31, 1953 but re-employed from April 1 subject to the rule, consented by March 23, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in February 1953, the respondent was informed by the Commissioner of Sales-tax, U.P. that his appointment would terminate on March 31, 1953 but he could be re- employed in the post but he will be subject to the rule set out earlier. The respondent was asked to intimate to the Government by March 23, 1953 whether he was prepared to be reemployed from April 1, 1953 on the said terms.

facts.text: Jugal Kishore Bhatt's appointment extended from April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter he continued in service up to March 31, 1954. Subsequently his appointment was extended for a period of one year from April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955.

facts.text: G.O. No. ST-896/X-911 D/55 dated April 27, 1955 extended Sales-tax Officer posts up to March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile by G.O. No. ST-896/X-911 D/55 dated April 27, 1955, the Governor was pleased to sanction the extension of the posts of Sales-tax Officers up to March 31, 1956.

facts.text: G.O. No. ST-2562/X-911 dated May 22, 1956 converted 61 temporary posts of S.T.Os to permanent w.e.f. April 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On May 22, 1956 the Governor was pleased to issue G.O. No.ST-2562/x-911-A. This G-O.is important. Hence we shall quote the same in full O. No. ST 2562/X-911 dated May 22, 1956 from the Deputy Secretary to Government to Commr. Sales Tax. Subject Conversion of sixty one temporary posts of S.T.O. into permanent one.

facts.text: State Government terminated Jugal Kishore Bhatt's services on May 1, 1958 by one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: On May 1, 1958, the State Government terminated the services of the respondent by giving him one months notice.

facts.text: Jugal Kishore Bhatt's representation against termination rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent represented against the notice terminating his service but his representation was rejected.

facts.text: Jugal Kishore Bhatt filed writ petition under Art. 226 challenging termination, accepted by single judge, affirmed by division bench.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter he challenged the order of his termination before the Allahabad High Court by means of a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution. His writ petition was accepted by the learned single judge and the impugned order was set aside. That order was affirmed by a division bench.

facts.text: Babu Singh Gaur appointed as temporary Panchayat Raj Inspector on June 6, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Now turning to the facts in Civil Appeal No. 1011 of 1966, the respondent therein was appointed as a temporary Panchayat Raj Inspector on June 6, 1949.

facts.text: Temporary posts under Panchayat Raj scheme declared substantive capacity under FR 26d retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: Officers appointed temporarily under the Panchayat Raj scheme were also declared to hold their temporary posts in a substantive capacity, within the meaning of the order of the Governor regarding Fundamental Rule 26 d  of the Financial Handbook Vol. II, Part II with retrospective effect from the date of their first appointment to those posts.

facts.text: Temporary posts under Panchayat Raj scheme converted into permanent posts subsequently.

anchor.surface_text: The temporary posts under the Panchayat Raj Scheme were converted into Permanent posts subsequently.

facts.text: Babu Singh Gaur's services terminated on September 12, 1958 by one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: The services of the respondent Babu Singh Gaur were terminated, by giving him one months notice, on September 12, 1958.

facts.text: Babu Singh Gaur filed writ petition under Art. 226, dismissed by single judge, allowed by Letters Patent Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Babu Singh Gaur also challenged his termination by means of a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the Allahabad High Court. His writ petition was dismissed by a single judge but in appeal the Letters Patent Bench allowed his plea and set aside the impugned order.

facts.text: It is admitted that respondents were appointed temporarily to temporary posts.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the respondents in both these appeals were appointed temporarily. At the time of their initial appointment, the posts to which they were appointed were also temporary.

facts.text: Appointments declared substantive capacity for FR 26d with retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime after their appointment, their appointments though temporary were declared to be on substantive capacity within the meaning of the order of the Governor regarding Fundamental Rule 26 d  Financial Handbook Vol. II, Part II with retrospective effect from the date of their first appointments to their posts.

facts.text: G.O. converting temporary posts to permanent stated confirmation of individual officers would issue separately.

anchor.surface_text: The order which converted those temporary posts into permanent posts specifically stated that order- regarding the confirmation of individual officers in these posts will issue separately.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeals, set aside High Court orders, dismissed writ petitions on April 30, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969.

facts.text: Babu Singh Gaur appointed in 1949, Jugal Kishore Bhatt in 1948, served government for long time.

anchor.surface_text: Before leaving these cases, we would like to impress on the government the hardship that is likely to be caused to the respondents in these appeals. Babu Singh Gaur was appointed as far back as 1949 and Jugal Kishore Bhatt in the year 1948. They have served the government for a very long time.

Appeals by special leave from the judgments and decrees dated February 12, 1965 and November 10, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos. 298 of 1960 and 483 of 1962 respectively. N. Dixit and 0. P. Rana, for the appellants

concepts.unlisted_description: Rule on increments during leave or interruption in temporary posts

anchor.surface_text: Fundamental Rule 26 d says If a government servants tenure of a temporary post is interrupted by duty in another post or by leave other than extraordinary leave or by foreign service, such duty, leave or foreign service counts for increments in the time-scale applicable to the temporary post if the government servants returns to the temporary post provided that the Government may, in any case where they are satisfied that the leave was taken on account of illness or for any other cause beyond the government servants control, direct that extraordinary leave shall be counted for increments under this clause.

concepts.interpretation: Deals only with leave and increments, not nature of appointment or tenure rights

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: pacity in permanent posts. A temporary government servant does number become a permanent Government servant unless he gets that capacity either under

concepts.unlisted_description: Rule on increments during leave or interruption in temporary posts

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any existing rules and orders on the subject, the services of a Government servant in temporary service shall be liable to termination at any time by notice in writing given either by the Government servant to the appointing authority or by the appointing authority to the government servant. The period of such notice shall be one month... This rule shall take immediate effect and shall apply to all persons who are appointed hereafter in a civil post in connection with the affairs of Uttar Pradesh...

concepts.interpretation: Applies to temporary government servants; allows termination by one month's notice even after posts become permanent; upheld as valid

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Governor regarding rule 26 d reads thus Under this rule if a government servants tenure of a temporary post is interrupted by leave, the leave counts for increments to the time-scale applicable to the temporary post, but under clause (b) of this rule if a government servant officiating in a permanent post takes leave... appointments to temporary posts, even of short duration are usually made in a substantive capacity.

concepts.interpretation: Substantive appointment to temporary post gives benefits for pay/leave but terminable by notice; does not confer permanency or right to post

anchor.surface_text: The position may, therefore, be summarised as follows In the absence of any special contract the substantive appointment to a permanent post gives the servant so appointed a right to hold the post until, under the rules he attains the age of superannuation or is compulsorily retired after having put in the prescribed number of years service or the post is abolished and his service cannot be terminated except by way of punishment for misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or any other disqualification found against him on proper enquiry after due notice to him.

concepts.interpretation: Arises only for substantive permanent post or fixed tenure temporary post; absent for temporary or officiating appointments

issues.text: Whether the order of the Governor declaring appointments to temporary posts in substantive capacity within the meaning of the order regarding Fundamental Rule 26d altered the temporary nature of the appointments for all purposes

anchor.surface_text: Officers appointed temporarily under the Panchayat Raj scheme were also declared to hold their temporary posts in a substantive capacity, within the meaning of the order of the Governor regarding Fundamental Rule 26 d of the Financial Handbook Vol. II, Part II with retrospective effect from the date of their first appointment to those posts. They were also made subject to the rule made under Art. 309 referred to earlier. The temporary posts under the Panchayat Raj Scheme were converted into Permanent posts subsequently. The services of the respondent Babu Singh Gaur were terminated, by giving him one months notice, on September 12, 1958. It is clear from the rules as well as the order of the Governor that they merely dealt with leave and increment.

issues.text: Whether conversion of temporary posts into permanent posts conferred on the temporary incumbents holding substantive capacity under FR 26d order a right to hold the permanent posts until superannuation or retirement

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Governor regarding rule 26 d reads thus Under this rule if a government servants tenure of a temporary post is interrupted by leave, the leave counts for increments to the time-scale applicable to the temporary post, but under clause (b) of this rule if a government servant officiating in a permanent post takes leave... appointments to temporary posts, even of short duration are usually made in a substantive capacity. The learned judges of the Letters Patent Bench thought that as Babu Singh Gaur and Jugal Kishore Bhatt were holding their posts in a substantive capacity, though temporarily, after the posts held by their, were made permanent, they must be held to have been holding those permanent posts in a substantive capacity.

issues.text: Whether the services of the temporary government servants were liable to termination by one month's notice under the rule framed by the Governor under Article 309 notwithstanding the posts becoming permanent and substantive capacity declaration under FR 26d

anchor.surface_text: In that year the Governor of U.P. in exercise of the powers conferred upon him by the provisions of Art. 309 of the Constitution made the following rule Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any existing rules and orders on the subject, the services of a Government servant in temporary service shall be liable to termination at any time by notice in writing given either by the Government servant to the appointing authority or by the appointing authority to the government servant. The period of such notice shall be one month... This rule shall take immediate effect and shall apply to all persons who are appointed hereafter in a civil post in connection with the affairs of Uttar Pradesh...

issues.text: A common question of law arises for decision in these two appeals

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde, J. These are appeals by special leave. A common question of law arises for decision in these two appeals. Hence it is convenient to consider them together. The material facts are more fully set out in Civil Appeal No. 1012 of 1966. We shall set out those facts in detail. We shall refer to the facts of Civil Appeal No. 1011 of 1966 thereafter, briefly. The respondent in Civil Appeal No. 1012 of 1966, Jugal Kishore Bhatt was appointed as the Sales-tax Officer on June 29, 1948 by the Governor of U.P.

arguments.claim: Holding posts in substantive capacity though temporary, after posts made permanent, means holding permanent posts in substantive capacity

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges of the Letters Patent Bench thought that as Babu Singh Gaur and Jugal Kishore Bhatt were holding their posts in a substantive capacity, though temporarily, after the posts held by their, were made permanent, they must be held to have been holding those permanent posts in a substantive capacity.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: eference will hereafter be made, his service had ripened into what is called a quasi permanent service. In State of Nagaland v. G. Vasantha 1 , this C

arguments.court_reasoning: Erroneous reasoning as substantive capacity limited to leave and increments, not nature of appointment or tenure

arguments.claim: Rules and Governor's order under FR 26d merely dealt with leave and increments, nothing to do with nature of appointment

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the rules as well as the order of the Governor that they merely dealt with leave and increment. That order has nothing to do with the nature of the appointment.

arguments.claim: Temporary appointments considered substantive only for specified purposes like leave/increments, not for all purposes including tenure

anchor.surface_text: The fact that for certain specified purposes those temporary appointments were to be considered to be in a substantive capacity, does not mean that the appointees were holding the posts in question in a substantive capacity for all purposes. For purposes other than mentioned in the order, their appointments continue to be temporary.

arguments.claim: G.O. converting temporary posts to permanent posts stated that confirmation of individual officers would issue separately

anchor.surface_text: The order which converted those temporary posts into permanent posts specifically stated that order- regarding the confirmation of individual officers in these posts will issue separately.

arguments.claim: No rule exists under which respondents were appointed permanently or in substantive capacity to permanent posts; they remained temporary servants

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the conversion of temporary posts into permanent posts, the Government did not consider the question as to who all should be confirmed. Obviously the government wanted to consider that question separately. ... A temporary government servant does not become a permanent Government servant unless he gets that capacity either under some rule or he is declared or appointed by the Government as a permanent government servant.

arguments.claim: Substantive appointment to temporary post is terminable by notice, as per Purshotam Lal Dhingra

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Purshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India considered in detail the nature of posts held by government servants. Dealing with the question of substantive appointment of a person to a temporary post, this Court observed at pp. 842 and 843 of the report The substantive appointment to a temporary post, under the rules, used to give the servant so appointed certain benefits regarding pay and leave, but was otherwise on the same footing as appointment to a temporary post on probation or on an officiating basis, that is to say, terminable by notice

arguments.claim: Appointment to temporary post, even substantive, gives no right to post unless quasi-permanent; right to hold post only for substantive permanent post or fixed term temporary

anchor.surface_text: The position may, therefore, be summarised as follows In the absence of any special contract the substantive appointment to a permanent post gives the servant so appointed a right to hold the post until, under the rules he attains the age of superannuation or is compulsorily retired ... Except in these two cases, the appointment to a post, permanent or temporary, on probation or on an officiating basis or a substantive appointment to a temporary post gives to the servant so appointed no right to the post

arguments.claim: Temporary servant's service terminable by notice even if post converted to permanent, as in State of Nagaland v. G. Vasantha

anchor.surface_text: In State of Nagaland v. G. Vasantha, this Court was called upon to decide the validity of termination of service of a government servant by giving him notice of termination as prescribed in the relevant Rules. ... Reversing the decision of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland, this Court held that the fact that the post which he was holding was converted into a permanent post did not confer on him any additional right.

arguments.claim: Temporary substantive appointment does not make one permanent government servant; services terminable by one month's notice

anchor.surface_text: The learned Counsel for the State contends that the plaintiff was a temporary servant and his services were liable to be terminated on a months notice and the fact that he was holding appointment as temporary substantive does not make the plaintiff a permanent government servant. There is force in this contention.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ision of the Allahabad High Court held that the service of the respondent therein was validly terminated by giving him one months numberice. Speaking

arguments.court_reasoning: Plaintiff not declared permanent; only posts made permanent, confirmation separate

arguments.claim: Abdul Khalik decision distinguishable because only some temporary posts converted to permanent there, whereas here all temporary posts converted

anchor.surface_text: That decision was tried to be distinguished on the ground that in that case, only some out of the several temporary posts had been converted into permanent posts, whereas in the cases before us all the temporary posts had been converted into permanent posts.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: There is force in this companytention. The learned Counsel for the plaintiff was number able to po

arguments.court_reasoning: This difference has no bearing on the ratio of that decision that temporary appointee gets no right merely because post made permanent

arguments.claim: Ratio of Abdul Khalik applies: temporary government servant does not get right to post merely because post converted to permanent

anchor.surface_text: We do not think this difference has any bearing on the ratio of that decision. The ratio of that decision is that a government servant temporarily appointed does not get a right to the post merely because the post held by him is converted into a permanent post.

arguments.claim: Services of temporary government servants liable to termination by one month's notice under rule framed by Governor under Art. 309

anchor.surface_text: In that year the Governor of U.P. in exercise of the powers conferred upon him by the provisions of Art. 309 of the Constitution made the following rule Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any existing rules and orders on the subject, the services of a Government servant in temporary service shall be liable to termination at any time by notice in writing ... The period of such notice shall be one month

holdings.text: The rules as well as the order of the Governor merely dealt with leave and increment. That order has nothing to do with the nature of the appointment. The fact that for certain specified purposes those temporary appointments were to be considered to be in a substantive capacity, does not mean that the appointees were holding the posts in question in a substantive capacity for all purposes. For purposes other than mentioned in the order, their appointments continue to be temporary.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the rules as well as the order of the Governor that they merely dealt with leave and increment. That order has nothing to do with the nature of the appointment. The fact that for certain specified purposes those temporary appointments were to be considered to be in a substantive capacity, does not mean that the appointees were holding the posts in question in a substantive capacity for all purposes. For purposes other than mentioned in the order, their appointments continue to be temporary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation limits FR 26d and Governor's order to leave and increments only, not tenure or nature of appointment.

holdings.text: The order which converted those temporary posts into permanent posts specifically stated that orders regarding the confirmation of individual officers in these posts will issue separately.

anchor.surface_text: The order which converted those temporary posts into permanent posts specifically stated that order- regarding the confirmation of individual officers in these posts will issue separately.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit language in G.O. requires separate confirmation orders, which were not issued.

holdings.text: A temporary government servant does not become a permanent Government servant unless he gets that capacity either under some rule or he is declared or appointed by the Government as a permanent government servant. Our attention has not been invited to any rule under which respondents in these appeals can be considered as having been appointed either permanently or in a substantive capacity to permanent posts. All along they continued to be temporary government servants whether the posts held by them were temporary posts or permanent posts.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the conversion of temporary posts into permanent posts, the Government did not consider the question as to who all should be confirmed. Obviously the government wanted to consider that question separately. ... A temporary government servant does not become a permanent Government servant unless he gets that capacity either under some rule or he is declared or appointed by the Government as a permanent government servant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of specific rule or declaration of permanency; no evidence provided.

holdings.text: The substantive appointment to a temporary post, under the rules, used to give the servant so appointed certain benefits regarding pay and leave, but was otherwise on the same footing as appointment to a temporary post on probation or on an officiating basis, that is to say, terminable by notice except where under the rules promulgated in 1949 to which reference will hereafter be made, his service had ripened into what is called a quasi permanent service.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Purshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India considered in detail the nature of posts held by government servants. Dealing with the question of substantive appointment of a person to a temporary post, this Court observed at pp. 842 and 843 of the report The substantive appointment to a temporary post, under the rules, used to give the servant so appointed certain benefits regarding pay and leave, but was otherwise on the same footing as appointment to a temporary post on probation or on an officiating basis, that is to say, terminable by notice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding Supreme Court precedent in Purshottam Lal Dhingra defines substantive temporary appointment as terminable.

holdings.text: The fact that the post which he was holding was converted into a permanent post did not confer on him any additional right. His service was terminable by giving him the prescribed notice under the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: In State of Nagaland v. G. Vasantha, this Court was called upon to decide the validity of termination of service of a government servant by giving him notice of termination as prescribed in the relevant Rules. ... Reversing the decision of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland, this Court held that the fact that the post which he was holding was converted into a permanent post did not confer on him any additional right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in State of Nagaland v. G. Vasantha directly holds post permanency does not alter temporary status.

holdings.text: Except in [cases of substantive permanent post or fixed term], the appointment to a post, permanent or temporary, on probation or on an officiating basis or a substantive appointment to a temporary post gives to the servant so appointed no right to the post and his service may be terminated unless his service had ripened into what is, in the service rules, called a quasi-permanent service.

anchor.surface_text: The position may, therefore, be summarised as follows In the absence of any special contract the substantive appointment to a permanent post gives the servant so appointed a right to hold the post until, under the rules he attains the age of superannuation or is compulsorily retired after having put in the prescribed number of years service or the post is abolished and his service cannot be terminated except by way of punishment for misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or any other disqualification found against him on proper enquiry after due notice to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of service law principles from precedent distinguishing rights based on appointment type.

holdings.text: A government servant temporarily appointed does not get a right to the post merely because the post held by him is converted into a permanent post.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think this difference has any bearing on the ratio of that decision. The ratio of that decision is that a government servant temporarily appointed does not get a right to the post merely because the post held by him is converted into a permanent post.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ratio from State of U.P. v. Abdul Khalik applies; respondent's distinction rejected.

holdings.text: The services of a Government servant in temporary service shall be liable to termination at any time by notice in writing... The period of such notice shall be one month.

anchor.surface_text: In that year the Governor of U.P. in exercise of the powers conferred upon him by the provisions of Art. 309 of the Constitution made the following rule Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any existing rules and orders on the subject, the services of a Government servant in temporary service shall be liable to termination at any time by notice in writing given either by the Government servant to the appointing authority or by the appointing authority to the government servant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule under Art. 309 applies to temporary service including substantive temporary posts; upheld via precedents.

holdings.text: For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Terminations valid as respondents were temporary servants liable to notice termination.

holdings.text: Before leaving these cases, we would like to impress on the government the hardship that is likely to be caused to the respondents in these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: Before leaving these cases, we would like to impress on the government the hardship that is likely to be caused to the respondents in these appeals. Babu Singh Gaur was appointed as far back as 1949 and Jugal Kishore Bhatt in the year 1948. They have served the government for a very long time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-binding sympathetic observation on long service.

precedents.citation: Purshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India 1 1958 S.C.R. 828

anchor.surface_text: Purshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India 1  companysidered in detail the nature of posts held by government ser-  1  1958 S.C.R. 828.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: nature of substantive appointment to a temporary post
precedents.cited_holding: The substantive appointment to a temporary post, under the rules, used to give the servant so appointed certain benefits regarding pay and leave, but was otherwise on the same footing as appointment to a temporary post on probation or on an officiating basis, that is to say, terminable by notice except where under the rules promulgated in 1949 [...] his service had ripened into what is called a quasi permanent service.

precedents.citation: State of Nagaland v. G. Vasantha 1 A.I.R. 1970 S.C. 537

anchor.surface_text: In State of Nagaland v. G. Vasantha 1 , this Court was called the effect of Fundamental Rules. [...] Sometime after his A.I.R. 1970 S.C. 537. appointment that post was companyverted into a permanent post.

precedents.case_name: State of Nagaland v. G. Vasantha
precedents.cited_proposition: effect of Fundamental Rules on nature of appointments; termination of temporary service even after post made permanent
precedents.cited_holding: Except in these two cases, the appointment to a post, permanent or temporary, on probation or on an officiating basis or a substantive appointment to a temporary post gives to the servant so appointed no right to the post and his service may be terminated unless his service had ripened into what is, in the service rules, called a quasi-permanent service.

precedents.citation: State of U.P. v. Abdul Khalik 1

anchor.surface_text: State of U.P. v. Abdul Khalik 1 . The facts of that case were substantially similar to the facts in than appeals.

precedents.case_name: State of U.P. v. Abdul Khalik
precedents.cited_proposition: temporary government servant holding post in temporary substantive capacity does not become permanent merely because post is converted to permanent; service terminable by one month's notice
precedents.cited_holding: the plaintiff was a temporary servant and his services were liable to be terminated on a months notice and the fact that he was holding appointment as temporary substantive does not make the plaintiff a permanent government servant.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969. but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts both in this Court as well as in the High Court.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed; High Court orders set aside; writ petitions dismissed
directions: parties to bear their own costs both in this Court as well as in the High Court

edges.explanation: Holding addresses the issue of whether Governor's order under FR 26d altered temporary nature by clarifying it does not affect appointment nature.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the rules as well as the order of the Governor that they merely dealt with leave and increment. That order has nothing to do with the nature of the appointment. The fact that for certain specified purposes those temporary appointments were to be considered to be in a substantive capacity, does not mean that the appointees were holding the posts in question in a substantive capacity for all purposes. For purposes other than mentioned in the order, their appointments continue to be temporary.

For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969. but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts both in this Court as well as in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the conversion of temporary posts into permanent posts, the Government did not consider the question as to who all should be confirmed. Obviously the government wanted to consider that question separately. ... A temporary government servant does not become a permanent Government servant unless he gets that capacity either under some rule or he is declared or appointed by the Government as a permanent government servant.

For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969. but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts both in this Court as well as in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Purshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India considered in detail the nature of posts held by government servants. Dealing with the question of substantive appointment of a person to a temporary post, this Court observed at pp. 842 and 843 of the report The substantive appointment to a temporary post, under the rules, used to give the servant so appointed certain benefits regarding pay and leave, but was otherwise on the same footing as appointment to a temporary post on probation or on an officiating basis, that is to say, terminable by notice

For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969. but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts both in this Court as well as in the High Court.

edges.explanation: h5 reinforces that service under substantive appointment to temporary post remains terminable post-conversion, aligning with c11

anchor.surface_text: In State of Nagaland v. G. Vasantha, this Court was called upon to decide the validity of termination of service of a government servant by giving him notice of termination as prescribed in the relevant Rules. ... Reversing the decision of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland, this Court held that the fact that the post which he was holding was converted into a permanent post did not confer on him any additional right.

For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969. but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts both in this Court as well as in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The position may, therefore, be summarised as follows In the absence of any special contract the substantive appointment to a permanent post gives the servant so appointed a right to hold the post until, under the rules he attains the age of superannuation or is compulsorily retired after having put in the prescribed number of years service or the post is abolished and his service cannot be terminated except by way of punishment for misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or any other disqualification found against him on proper enquiry after due notice to him.

For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969. but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts both in this Court as well as in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think this difference has any bearing on the ratio of that decision. The ratio of that decision is that a government servant temporarily appointed does not get a right to the post merely because the post held by him is converted into a permanent post.

For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969. but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts both in this Court as well as in the High Court.

edges.explanation: Holding addresses issue of liability to termination under Art. 309 rule by stating the rule's text.

anchor.surface_text: In that year the Governor of U.P. in exercise of the powers conferred upon him by the provisions of Art. 309 of the Constitution made the following rule Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any existing rules and orders on the subject, the services of a Government servant in temporary service shall be liable to termination at any time by notice in writing given either by the Government servant to the appointing authority or by the appointing authority to the government servant.

For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969. but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts both in this Court as well as in the High Court.

For the reasons mentioned above, we allow these appeals, set aside the orders of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions C.A.S. No,. 782 783/66 decided in April 30,1969. but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts both in this Court as well as in the High Court.
